Not to oversimplify things but the Cape ratio has remained high for well over a decade, and that is for a reason, as bond returns have declined, and gdp growth has diminished, we are in a mature economy with diminishing returns, therefore investors accept less of a return on investment in all classes.

With interest rates having been low for over a decade with easy borrowing standards, investment is played out, we are reaching levels of investment efficiency we have not seen before. Add to that the wash of money the fed is throwing in, and the vibrant junk markets, and it's a simple case of investment inflation, too much money seeking too little return.

Is it a bubble? Depends on your perspective, using periods of high gdp growth, or high interest rates or high inflation it looks like it, but as we approach the zero bound for those three, this is starting to look more like the new normal.

zero inflation=zero interest rates=zero gdp growth=zero return on investment

Professor Krugman has long argued for single-payer, and, as a less desirable alternative, but possibly more achievable, system the Swiss model, where the insurance companies are highly regulated, and are essentially forced to compete on efficacy of coverage.  The ACA has some of that model, but since , in this country insurance is regulated state by state, it cannot approach the universality of the Swiss model.

I am all in favor of Medicare, and I hope Prof. Krugman's optimistic interpretation of the slower increase in Medicare costs than predicted is correct and that the cost saving measures are indeed a large part of the cause for these reduced expenditure. I have been a fan of Medicare since starting on it with my retirement in 2011, even compared to the universal health insurance I experienced over many years in Germany.

What worries me is that even the cited article on Vox states that the causes for this decline are really not known, and only reports on some GUESSES.

As a personal anecdote, I am finding that a number of charges (e.g. for lab work as part of the annual Wellness Checkup) are being denied by Medicare (and thus also by my Supplemental insurance), where even the Medicare site itself states that these tests are covered every 12 months. I currently have a number of "Appeals" pending about such rejected charges.

This could be just a problem with the cutover to "Noridian" processing service as of Sept. 2013, but I am hoping that the cost reductions cited by Prof. Krugman are not a sign of "incentives" by Medicare to Noridian to reduce claims - things like that are know to happen in the private insurance business when the good old profit motive rears its ugly head.

Our model for better quantity and quality of health care should be those avanced western European countries, the ones that Republicans call "socialist". They cover everyone, not just some people, for less money (both in total and as a percentage of GNP) than we do, and provide better health outcomes and greater longevity.

Here are some solutions, for all of which we can emulate the Europeans. Reduce the amount of time and testing companies need to get a new drug approved, reduce the amount of time on which the developer has an exclusive patent, and further limit drug company marketing to doctors. Tighten the standards for "copycat" drugs, whereby a minor alteration to a molecule allows another period of exclusive patent protection.

Reduce Federal student aid to would-be medical specialists; we have too many. Increase Federal student aid for would-be general practitioners; we have too few. Grant greater loan forgivesness to those who work in areas that are short of doctors, and less or none to those who flock with the medical herd.

Thanks to Republicans, the Federal overnment is not allowed to negotiate with drug companies when it buys medicine. What a horrendous violation of free market principles. Allow such negotiation.

In this age of Big Data, let's have lots more monitoring, so we can see what works and what doesn't. Better information means better decisions.

Require doctors to post procedure prices and insurers to post reimbursements.
